bibl.title: >Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 1, 1905

div1.p: Gorgas writes about the use of pyrethrum in the Canal Zone for the treatment of yellow fever and plague.

div1.head: Letter from William Crawford Gorgas to Jefferson Randolph Kean, July 1, 1905
div1.opener:
C. S. O., No 1280 W
ISTHMIAN CANAL COMMISSION
OFFICE OF CHIEF SANITARY OFFICER
ANCON. CANAL ZONE.
July 1, 1905.
Maj. J.R. Kean,
Office of Surgeon-General, U.S.A.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear Kean:-
div1.p:
Yours of the 17th received. If yellow fever should continue
indefinitely as it is at present, we should use in the course of the year about
200 tons of pyrethrum. Outside of yellow fever we would have very little use
for it; probably six or eight tons a year would cover all our needs.

Everything is running along smoothly. Yellow fever seems to be on
the decline. For the first ten days in June we had 20 cases; second ten days
28 cases; last ten days 8 cases. One case of plague on the 15th, and none
since.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, W. C. Gorgas.
Chief Sanitary Officer.
